word.literal: Time and tide wait for no one
to not be able to see

sentence.idiomatic: Time and tide wait for no one. At forty years old, wrinkles had already appeared on her face. One can no longer see a trace of her beauty queen days.

word.literal: Time and tide wait for no one

sentence.idiomatic: In those years, I was a marathon champion. It's a pity that time and tide wait for no one. Now to go out and walk even a few steps I need my grandson to support me.

word.literal: Time and tide wait for no one

sentence.idiomatic: Time and tide wait for no man. When you get to my age, you can't deny your age.
Do you know what I went through in order to get the tickets to Jacky Cheung's concert?

word.literal: to take a lot of effort

sentence.idiomatic: There are so many people on the bus--to try to squeeze on would take too much effort.

word.literal: to take a lot of effort

sentence.idiomatic: He had a foundation in Chinese characters, so when he started studying Chinese he didn't have to put in much effort at all.
I have pondered over it for half the day, and still don't understand what her words meant.
These past few days I have been pondering the issue of how to promote the new product, but I still haven't gotten any ideas.
You sitting here blindly pondering over the question forever is of no use. You'd better go and ask the teacher for some guidance.
Did birds really evolve from dinosaurs?
The marchers and the armed police are clashing. If it's not handled appropriately, it will ultimately devolve into an incident of violent bloodshed.
After the media caused a hubbub about the Chongqing "nailhouse" incident, it changed from an incident in a person's life to an entertainment spectacle.
Along with the increasingly frequent diplomatic exchanges between China and foreign countries, more and more loanwords are coming into the Chinese language.
Loanwords in Chinese are primarily transliterations, mainly originating from English and Japanese.
The word "cement" in Shanghainese actually is a loanword. Do you know which English word it originated from?
Life is a riddle; every person uses their whole life in deciphering it.
If you want to decipher a realistic novel, you can begin by looking at the background of the era when the work was written.
The hip new generation nowadays really confuses people. Oddly enough, they take "disagreeable" and decipher it as "endearing" or "never boring."
This is between him and I--what does it have to do with you?
Your answer and my question are totally unrelated. Are you thinking about other things again?
From this day on, we will go our own separate ways and have nothing to do with each other.
Wow, you're so hard-working, studying Japanese!

word.literal: Time and tide wait for no one

sentence.idiomatic: Yeah, I just started. Time and tide wait for no man. Studying stuff now is really tiring.
But Japanese and Chinese are really similar, right? It's got to be easier than studying English, anyway.
I used to think that. Now I find that Japanese is only easy in the beginning, for writing and pronunciation and stuff. But if you want to dig deeper in your studies it's difficult.
Doesn't Japanese have lots of Chinese characters? We Chinese can just put some thought into it and then we'll get it. But besides Chinese characters there are also some weird symbols. What are those?

You're talking about hiragana and katakana. They're the phonetic writing system of Japanese. In Japanese, the same sounds correspond to both the written forms of hiragana and of katakana. Hiragana evolved from the grass script form of Chinese characters, and are used in typical writing. Katakana originated from the radicals of Chinese characters, and is mainly used to express foreign loanwords or emphasis.
Oh, I know this: a lot of English words were directly transliterated into Japanese words.

word.literal: to not be able to tell

sentence.idiomatic: Yeah, but they still have Japanese characteristics. You can't tell at all what they were originally.
So are the Chinese characters in Japanese all traditional characters?

Traditional characters comprise the majority, but there are also a few Japanese character simplifications that are somewhat different from our simplified characters. For example, the ``patsu" in ``shuppatsu." This character doesn't exist in Chinese.
Why does it seem so complicated?

The really complicated stuff is still coming. For example, the multiple readings for each character, and the grammar. In the end, I've discovered that languages too similar to Mandarin are actually harder to learn, because you'll be applying your Chinese concepts when deciphering them.
Ah, I think that as long as it's a language, it's always going to be difficult. Take a look at English. It's not at all similar to Chinese, but I can't even learn it, right?

word.literal: Time and tide wait for no one
to put forth a lot of effort; tiring
to be concerned with; to have to do with
things are always difficult at the start
